paragraphs.text:
%md
# <center>Project 3</center>
# <center>The World Happiness Report</center>
## <center>Chao-Ting Chang, Salva Rocher, Fabia Höhne</center>

msg.data:
Project 3

The World Happiness Report

Chao-Ting Chang, Salva Rocher, Fabia Höhne

paragraphs.text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

df_countries = pd.read_csv("/home/chao/Desktop/Ironhack/Projects/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/Data/countries.csv")
df_happiness = pd.read_csv("/home/chao/Desktop/Ironhack/Projects/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/Data/happiness_all_constant.csv")
df_elections = pd.read_csv("/home/chao/Desktop/Ironhack/Projects/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/Data/Elections_10_countries.csv")
df_happiness = df_happiness[df_happiness["Year"] > 2010]

%md
## <center>Question</center>
### <center>Is there a correlation between the happiness of a country and the vote proportion of extreme political parties?</center>

msg.data:
Question

Is there a correlation between the happiness of a country and the vote proportion of extreme political parties?

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Hypothesis

  
  
### “There will be a negative correlation between extremism (both left and right) and the happiness of a country”

msg.data:
Hypothesis

“There will be a negative correlation between extremism (both left and right) and the happiness of a country”

paragraphs.text:
%md
## About the project
Specification:  

- EU countries
- Initial focus on the overall happiness index

Looking for:  

- Relationship between collective happiness and extreme ideology politics
- Trens over time in one country

msg.data:
About the project

Specification:

  • EU countries
  • Initial focus on the overall happiness index

Looking for:

  • Relationship between collective happiness and extreme ideology politics
  • Trens over time in one country

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Data sources
- Happiness Index report (from 2011-2019)
    * Wikipedia (web scraping)
    * csv. HI reports from 2011 to 2019

- Election data (from 2011)  
    *  Web scraping (trails and fails)
    *  .csv creation with information on elections from various polls

msg.data:
Data sources

  • Happiness Index report (from 2011-2019)

    • Wikipedia (web scraping)
    • csv. HI reports from 2011 to 2019

  • Election data (from 2011)

    • Web scraping (trails and fails)
    • .csv creation with information on elections from various polls

paragraphs.text:
%md
# <center>Results</center>

msg.data: Results

paragraphs.text:
%md
The analysis was carried out on all ten countries of our initial research.  For representation purposes, we will breakdown the results we obtained for the countries of Austria and Belgium, which we grouped into one graph as the results are very similar. This example best represents our hypothesis (for further results, please see the Appendix at the end of the file).

msg.data: The analysis was carried out on all ten countries of our initial research. For representation purposes, we will breakdown the results we obtained for the countries of Austria and Belgium, which we grouped into one graph as the results are very similar. This example best represents our hypothesis (for further results, please see the Appendix at the end of the file).

paragraphs.text:
%md
## <center>Austria & Belgium</center>

msg.data: Austria & Belgium

paragraphs.title: Yearly Happiness Index
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT df_happiness.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_happiness.Score Score FROM df_happiness JOIN df_countries ON df_happiness.id_country = df_countries.id WHERE Country = "Austria" OR Country = "Belgium"

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Extreme Party Vote Proportion
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT df_elections.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_elections.proportion_votes Votes, df_elections.extreme_type  Extreme_type FROM df_elections JOIN df_countries ON df_elections.id_country = df_countries.id WHERE Country = "Austria" OR Country = "Belgium"

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
Year	Country	Votes	Extreme_type
2013	Austria	1.0	Left
2013	Austria	20.5	Right
2017	Austria	0.8	Left
2017	Austria	26.0	Right
2014	Belgium	1.33	Left
2014	Belgium	2.67	Right
2019	Belgium	8.0	Left
2019	Belgium	12.0	Right

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the diagram above, we see the trend that is described in our hypothesis. Our assumption is, that the initial drop of happiness, from 2013 to 2014 and the remaining lowered level, has led to a change in the proportion, remaining low after that point. When we compare that timeframe to the election results, we see that after that decrease in 2014, for the next elections the proportion of extreme votes has risen in relation to the previous ones.

msg.data: In the diagram above, we see the trend that is described in our hypothesis. Our assumption is, that the initial drop of happiness, from 2013 to 2014 and the remaining lowered level, has led to a change in the proportion, remaining low after that point. When we compare that timeframe to the election results, we see that after that decrease in 2014, for the next elections the proportion of extreme votes has risen in relation to the previous ones.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# <center>Overall Happiness Index vs. Extreme Party Vote Proportion</center>

msg.data: Overall Happiness Index vs. Extreme Party Vote Proportion

paragraphs.text:
%md
For our second analysis, we chose to show the change of the happiness index over time in the individual countries and compare that to the results of the elections in given countries over the timeframe.
Here, it is important to notice that every country has different tendencies in the political spectrum. We also notice that we have a very small sample of election results, which leads to a lower significance of our analysis.

msg.data:
For our second analysis, we chose to show the change of the happiness index over time in the individual countries and compare that to the results of the elections in given countries over the timeframe.
Here, it is important to notice that every country has different tendencies in the political spectrum. We also notice that we have a very small sample of election results, which leads to a lower significance of our analysis.

paragraphs.title: Extreme Party Vote Proportion vs. Happiness Index
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT df_happiness.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_happiness.Score Score, df_elections.proportion_votes Votes, df_elections.extreme_type Extreme_type  FROM df_happiness JOIN df_countries ON df_happiness.id_country = df_countries.id JOIN df_elections ON df_happiness.id_country = df_elections.id_country AND df_happiness.year = df_elections.year

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md

# <center>Correlation of Happiness Index and Vote Proportion<center>

msg.data: Correlation of Happiness Index and Vote Proportion

paragraphs.title: Spain
paragraphs.text:
%python
spain = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Spain"]
spain = spain.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del spain["id_country"]
spain = spain.groupby("year").sum()
spain = spain.drop([2012, 2013, 2014, 2017]).reset_index()
spain = spain.replace(0,np.nan)
spain["proportion_votes"][3] = 21.08
spain["proportion_votes"] = spain["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
spain_corr = spain.corr(method="pearson")
spain_corr["proportion_votes"]

msg.data:
year                                 0.989967
Score                               -0.711967
GDP                                 -0.683752
Social support                      -0.702432
Healthy life expectancy             -0.676258
Freedom                             -0.742715
Generosity                           0.937388
Perceptions of corruption           -0.728429
Confidence in national government   -0.700470
proportion_votes                     1.000000
Name: proportion_votes, dtype: float64

paragraphs.title: Sweden
paragraphs.text:
%python
sweden = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Sweden"]
sweden = sweden.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del sweden["id_country"]
sweden = sweden.groupby("year").sum()
sweden = sweden.drop([2011, 2012, 2015, 2016]).reset_index()
sweden = sweden.replace(0,np.nan)
sweden["proportion_votes"] = sweden["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
sweden_corr = sweden.corr(method="pearson")
sweden_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.text: %md

%md
# <center>Possible developments</center>

As we now have a basic analysis done, it would be interesting to keep developing this research to obtain a more significant and well-rounded result.
This could be done in a number of ways; however, we do have to consider that we only have data official and consistent data from 2011 onwards. The following two where our suggestions as they peaked our interest the most:
-    A further analysis including all European countries (more data), with more election results. We could, for example, extract results form more than one type of elections (provincial, parliamentary, etc.) to obtain data from more years. Added to this we could consider other factors, such as immigration flow, rise in nationalism, and government investment into national resources to obtain a fuller image of the environment and reduce the variables we do not control.
-    Similarly, to the above suggestion, the research method could be applied to a global sample. Taking into consideration not only the rise of extremism, but also different political systems.

msg.data:
Possible developments

As we now have a basic analysis done, it would be interesting to keep developing this research to obtain a more significant and well-rounded result.
This could be done in a number of ways; however, we do have to consider that we only have data official and consistent data from 2011 onwards. The following two where our suggestions as they peaked our interest the most:
- A further analysis including all European countries (more data), with more election results. We could, for example, extract results form more than one type of elections (provincial, parliamentary, etc.) to obtain data from more years. Added to this we could consider other factors, such as immigration flow, rise in nationalism, and government investment into national resources to obtain a fuller image of the environment and reduce the variables we do not control.
- Similarly, to the above suggestion, the research method could be applied to a global sample. Taking into consideration not only the rise of extremism, but also different political systems.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# <center>Conclusion</center>
Our main conclusion is that there is an observable correlation between the two factors, proving our hypothesis correct.
However, as previously mentioned, we do not have enough data on elections over the years to make a firm conclusion on the matter (high correlations might be due to a small sample size).
It is also important to note, that the topic chosen is very susceptible to exterior variables that are not included in our analysis, so further research and data is needed to be able to reproduce more reliable results.

msg.data:
Conclusion

Our main conclusion is that there is an observable correlation between the two factors, proving our hypothesis correct.
However, as previously mentioned, we do not have enough data on elections over the years to make a firm conclusion on the matter (high correlations might be due to a small sample size).
It is also important to note, that the topic chosen is very susceptible to exterior variables that are not included in our analysis, so further research and data is needed to be able to reproduce more reliable results.

### Correlation by country

msg.data: Correlation by country

paragraphs.title: Belgium
paragraphs.text:
%python
belgium = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Belgium"]
belgium = belgium.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del belgium["id_country"]
belgium = belgium.groupby("year").sum()
belgium = belgium.drop([2011, 2012, 2015, 2016, 2017]).reset_index()
belgium = belgium.replace(0,np.nan)
belgium["proportion_votes"][2] = 20
belgium["proportion_votes"] = belgium["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
belgium_corr = belgium.corr(method="pearson")
belgium_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.title: Netherlands
paragraphs.text:
%python
netherlands = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Netherlands"]
netherlands = netherlands.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del netherlands["id_country"]
netherlands = netherlands.groupby("year").sum()
netherlands = netherlands.drop([2013, 2014, 2015, 2018]).reset_index()
netherlands = netherlands.replace(0,np.nan)
netherlands["proportion_votes"] = netherlands["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
netherlands_corr = netherlands.corr(method="pearson")
netherlands_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.title: Denmark
paragraphs.text:
%python
denmark = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Denmark"]
denmark = denmark.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del denmark["id_country"]
denmark = denmark.groupby("year").sum()
denmark = denmark.drop([2011, 2012, 2013, 2016, 2017]).reset_index()
denmark = denmark.replace(0,np.nan)
denmark["proportion_votes"][3] = 18.43
denmark["proportion_votes"] = denmark["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
denmark_corr = denmark.corr(method="pearson")
denmark_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.title: Austria
paragraphs.text:
austria = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Austria"]
austria = austria.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del austria["id_country"]
austria = austria.groupby("year").sum()
austria = austria.replace(0,np.nan)
austria = austria.drop([2011, 2014, 2015, 2018]).reset_index()
austria["proportion_votes"] = austria["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
austria_corr = austria.corr(method="pearson")
austria_corr["proportion_votes"]
